[[File:Adebowale Adefuye.jpg|alt=Adebowale Adefuye, Ambassador of Nigeria to the United States|thumb|Adefuye during a White House visit on March 29, 2010]] '''Adebowale Ibidapo Adefuye''' (January 1947 – August 27, 2015) was a Nigerian historian and diplomat.
==Academic career== Born in [[Ijebu-Igbo]], Adefuye attended the [[University of Ibadan]], first graduating in 1969.<ref name=N24>{{cite news|title=Nigerian Ambassador to the US passes away|url=http://www.news24.com.ng/National/News/Nigerian-Ambassador-to-the-US-passes-away-20150828|accessdate=30 August 2015|agency=News 24 Nigeria|date=28 August 2015}}</ref> He obtained a Ph.D in history from the same institution in 1973.<ref name=SahRep/> During his academic career, Adefuye was named a Fulbright Scholar and used the funds to do research at [[Columbia University]], the [[University of North Florida]], and the [[University of Florida]].<ref name=pt>{{cite news|title=Nigerian Ambassador to U.S., Adebowale Adefuye, dead — Report|url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/top-news/189115-nigerian-ambassador-to-u-s-adebowale-adefuye-dead-report.html|accessdate=30 August 2015|work=Premium Times|date=28 August 2015}}</ref> Adefuye taught at the [[University of Lagos]], heading the school's history department from 1985 to 1987.<ref name=SahRep/>
==Diplomatic career== He was named the Ambassador to Jamaica in 1987, serving until 1991. During that period, Adefuye also concurrently served as the ambassador to Belize and Haiti. He was then the Deputy High Commissioner to the United Kingdom. Adefuye left that post to serve as the deputy director of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]] for fourteen years. After leaving the Commonwealth, he became an advisor to the [[Economic Community of West African States]] in 2008.<ref name=tnn>{{cite news|title=Adefuye died in US hospital, says Ministry of Foreign Affairs|url=http://thenewsnigeria.com.ng/2015/08/adefuye-died-in-us-hospital-says-ministry-of-foreign-affairs/|accessdate=30 August 2015|publisher=The News Nigeria|date=28 August 2015}}</ref> President [[Goodluck Jonathan]] appointed Adefuye the ambassador to the United States in 2010. During his tenure, Adefuye continually advocated for the United States to provide more military aid to Nigeria to effectively counter the forces of [[Boko Haram]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Grady|first1=Siobhán|title=Outspoken Nigerian Envoy to Washington Dies Suddenly|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/08/28/outspoken-nigerian-envoy-to-washington-dies-suddenly/|accessdate=30 August 2015|work=Foreign Policy|date=28 August 2015}}</ref> He was recalled in 2015 after [[Muhammadu Buhari]] was sworn in as [[president of Nigeria]].<ref name=SahRep>{{cite news|title=Nigerian Ambassador To The U.S. Ade Adefuye Is Dead|url=http://saharareporters.com/2015/08/27/nigerian-ambassador-us-ade-adefuye-dead|accessdate=30 August 2015|publisher=Sahara Reporters|date=27 August 2015}}</ref>
He died in Washington, D.C. on August 27, 2015,<ref name=pnn>{{cite news|title=Senate president, Saraki, others mourn late ambassador|url=http://pulse.ng/local/adebowale-adefuye-senate-president-saraki-others-mourn-late-ambassador-id4117047.html|accessdate=30 August 2015|publisher=Pulse News Nigeria|date=29 August 2015}}</ref> of a heart attack.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nigeria confirms death of envoy to US |url=http://www.dispatchtimes.com/nigeria-confirms-death-of-envoy-to-us/69436/ |accessdate=30 August 2015 |work=Dispatch Times |date=29 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150918211221/http://www.dispatchtimes.com/nigeria-confirms-death-of-envoy-to-us/69436/ |archivedate=18 September 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Oluwarotimi|first1=Abiodun|title=How Nigeria’s Ambassador To US, Professor Adefuye, Died|url=http://leadership.ng/news/456990/how-nigerias-ambassador-to-us-professor-adefuye-died|accessdate=30 August 2015|work=Leadership|date=28 August 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150901000026/http://leadership.ng/news/456990/how-nigerias-ambassador-to-us-professor-adefuye-died|archive-date=2015-09-01|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Adefuye, Adebowale}}

[[File:KaliningradOB.png|thumb|The Sambia Peninsula, Bay of Gdańsk and Vistula Lagoon; the area of the "Amber Coast")]] [[File:Pribrezhnyje yantarnyje razrabotki.jpg|thumb|Open-pit mining near Jantarny (Sambia Peninsula, Kaliningrad Oblast, Russia)]] [[File:Colours of Baltic Amber.jpg|thumb|Different colours of Baltic amber.]] The '''Amber Coast''' is the name given to a coastal strip of the [[Baltic Sea]] in the northwest of [[Kaliningrad]] ([[Russia]], [[Kaliningrad]] [[Oblast]], [[Sambia]] Peninsula, formerly northern [[East Prussia]] in [[Germany]]). In this area [[amber]] ([[Baltic amber]]) has been excavated since the mid-19th century and up to today in open-pit mining. Two deposits – Palmnikenskoe and Primorskoe, containing 80% of world amber reserves, were found near [[Yantarny, Kaliningrad Oblast|Yantarny]] on the Western coast of the [[Sambia Peninsula]] in 1948-1951’s.<ref>[https://leta.st/blog/2016/07/history-of-russian-amber-1/ "The History of Russian Amber, Part 1: The Beginning"], Leta.st</ref>
==History== Scientists believe that amber was deposited during the [[Upper Eocene]] and [[Lower Oligocene]] in a [[River delta|delta]] of a prehistoric river, in a shallow part of a marine basin.<ref name="Rice2006">{{cite book|author=Patty C. Rice|title=Amber: Golden Gem of the Ages|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g6NVVpqhixIC&pg=PA22|accessdate=7 March 2011|date=15 September 2006|publisher=Patty Rice|isbn=978-1-4259-3849-9|pages=22''ff''}}</ref> In addition to the coast near Kaliningrad, amber is also found elsewhere in the Baltic Sea region.<ref name="Rice2006"/> The deposits are found mostly in the "blue earth [[glauconite]]", a layer 1 to 17.5 meters thick found 25 to 40 meters from the surface.<ref name="Rice2006"/> In addition to the Sambia region, amber is gathered in noticeable amounts at German, Polish and Lithuanian Baltic beaches<ref name="Rice2006"/> (areas of the [[Bay of Gdańsk]] as well as the [[Vistula Lagoon]]), the western coast of [[Denmark]]<ref name="Rice2006"/> and the [[Frisian Islands]].<ref name="Rice2006"/> Small amounts of Baltic amber can even be found outside the Baltic region, for example on the coastline of the south east of England.<ref name="Rice2006"/>
However, about 90%<ref name="AmericaSociety1996">{{cite book|author1=Gemological Institute of America|author2=American Gem Society|title=Gems and gemology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hkvzAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=8 March 2011|year=1996|publisher=Gemological Institute of America.|page=74}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://gurukul.ucc.american.edu/ted/amber.htm |title=Amber Trade and the Environment in the Kaliningrad Oblast |access-date=2011-03-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120706182814/http://gurukul.ucc.american.edu/ted/amber.htm |archive-date=2012-07-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> to 98%<ref name="Rice2006"/> of all output of amber has been produced in the Sambia region (now a Russian [[exclave]], formerly in [[Eastern Prussia]] and the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]]).<ref name="Rice2006"/> The Sambian amber-producing region is a square of about 30–40 km (20–25 miles), although geologists estimate there are deposits beyond the region of the main excavations.<ref name="Rice2006"/> A potential nearby source of amber is the [[Courish Lagoon]].<ref name="Rice2006"/> Amber excavation is overseen by the [[Russian Amber Company]] (''Ruskij Jantar'').<ref name="Rice2006"/><ref name="Rice2006-2">{{cite book|author=Patty C. Rice|title=Amber: Golden Gem of the Ages|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g6NVVpqhixIC&pg=PA116|accessdate=7 March 2011|date=15 September 2006|publisher=Patty Rice|isbn=978-1-4259-3849-9|pages=116''ff''}}</ref>
The Amber Coast is mentioned as early as by [[Publius Cornelius Tacitus|Tacitus]] in his work ''Germania''.<ref name=And37>K. Andrée: ''Der Bernstein und seine Bedeutung in Natur- und Geisteswissenschaften, Kunst und Kunstgewerbe, Technik, Industrie und Handel.'' Königsberg 1937.</ref><ref>F. Waldmann: ''Der Bernstein im Altertum - Eine historisch-philologische Skizze.'' Fellin 1883.</ref>
==Other uses== Another coastal strip referred to as “amber coast” is the Costa de Ambar (also known as “Costambar”) in the west of [[Puerto Plata (city)|Puerto Plata]] ([[Hispaniola]], [[Dominican Republic]]). In this area there are a number of small shaft mines, from which is excavated the so-called "[[Dominican amber]]".<ref>George O. Poinar, Jr.: ''Life in amber.'' Stanford 1992</ref> The Dominican amber production site is the world's second-largest, although compared to the Baltic region it is "a distant second".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fossilmuseum.net/Tree_of_Life/FossilAmber.htm |title=Fossil Amber or Fossil Resin |publisher=Virtual Fossil Museum |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.sjsu.edu/faculty/watkins/amber.htm The Economic History of Amber] * [http://www.lithaz.org/lith/amber.html Baltic Amber]

{{Other uses|Crossroads (disambiguation)}} {{notability|date=May 2018}} {{italic title}} :''Not to be confused with [[America at the Crossroads]], an unrelated book by [[Francis Fukuyama]].''
'''''America at a Crossroads''''' is a documentary miniseries concerning the issues facing the [[United States|United States of America]] as related to the [[War on Terrorism]]. It aired originally on [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] television.
The miniseries initially consisted of 11 independently produced ''aired'' episodes, and premiered April 15–20, 2007 on PBS.<ref>PBS.org: [https://www.pbs.org/weta/crossroads/?campaign=pbshomefeatures_1_americaatacrossroads_2007-04-19 ''America at a Crossroads'' homepage.] Retrieved April 19, 2007.</ref> Its executive producers are [[Jeff Bieber]] and [[Dalton Delan]]; series producer is Leo Eaton and it is presented by [[Robert MacNeil]].<ref>PBS.org: [https://www.pbs.org/weta/crossroads/about/series_credits.html ''America at a Crossroads'' production credits.] Retrieved April 19, 2007.</ref> Its music score is composed by Canadian musician [[Mark Korven]].
==Subject matter== ''America at a Crossroads'' explores the challenges confronting the post-9/11 world — including the war on terrorism; the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan; the experience of American troops serving abroad; the struggle for balance within the Muslim world; and global perspectives on America's role overseas.
Aimed at creating a national dialogue surrounding the crucial issues explored in the series, an extensive media and outreach campaign in more than 25 communities accompanies the series. The campaign features screening events with the filmmakers and their subjects in discussions with United States military personnel, leading policy experts, leaders of the Islamic community, scholars from across the country as well as members of the public.
==Episode list== *Spring 2007 (Premier Series): **Jihad: The Men and Ideas Behind Al-Qaeda **Warriors **Operation Homecoming: Writing the Wartime Experience **Gangs of Iraq **The Case for War: In Defense of Freedom **Europe's 9/11 **The Muslim Americans **Faith Without Fear **Struggle for the Soul of Islam: Inside Indonesia **Security Versus Liberty: The Other War **The Brotherhood
===Removed from Premier Series=== *Islam vs. Islamists: Voices from the Muslim Center **Was aired on the [[Fox News Channel]] as ''[[Banned by PBS: Muslims Against Jihad]]''
===List of Additional Episodes=== *Summer 2007: **Kansas to Kandahar: Citizen Soldiers at War **The Anti-Americans (a hate/love relationship) **Inside America's Empire *Fall 2007: **Homegrown: Islam in Prison **Campus Battleground
==Criticism== One film, ''The Case for War: In Defense of Freedom'', in which [[Richard Perle]] presented his view of the challenges facing the U.S. generated considerable controversy.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/01/arts/television/01jens.html?_r=2&ref=arts&oref=slogin&oref=slogin | title = PBS Buys a Lot of Arguments for $20 Million | publisher = New York Times | date = 2007-04-01 | first=Elizabeth | last=Jensen | accessdate=April 23, 2010 }}</ref> Some critics complained that the film failed to adequately challenge Perle's views.<ref>[http://blog.wired.com/defense/2007/04/the_frog_of_war.html Wired Blogs: The World According to Richard Perle]</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' called the film "a fascinating study in rationalization, a lighter, less repentant version of ''[[The Fog of War]]'', [[Errol Morris]]'s documentary about [[Robert S. McNamara]]".<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/17/arts/television/17free.html?_r=3&oref=slogin&oref=slogin&oref=slogin | title = Advocate of the War Explores Its Impact | publisher = New York Times | date = 2007-04-17 | first=Alessandra | last=Stanley | accessdate=April 23, 2010 }}</ref> One critic complained that PBS's endorsement of the [[neoconservative]] viewpoint in this film was so misguided, that PBS viewers should express their disgust by "either cutting off donations or at least demanding back a percentage of what they've already given".<ref>{{cite news | url = http://baltimorechronicle.com/2007/041907Parry.shtml | title = Time for PBS to Go? | publisher = Baltimore Chronicle | date = 2007-04-19 }}</ref> Conversely, the producers of an unaired segment, ''[[Islam vs. Islamists]]'', claimed they had been victims of liberal bias and subsequently aired their documentary on the [[Fox News Channel]] under the provocative title ''[[Banned by PBS: Muslims Against Jihad]]''.
==See also== *[[War against Islam]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[https://www.pbs.org/weta/crossroads/?campaign=pbshomefeatures_1_americaatacrossroads_2007-04-19 Official site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:America At A Crossroads}} [[Category:PBS network shows]] [[Category:War on Terror]] [[Category:Documentary television series about war]]
